articles.headline: Engineers Allege Hiring Collusion in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: A class-action suit by Silicon Valley engineers against companies including Google, Apple and Intel has revealed details of an agreement among them not to cold-call one another’s employees.
articles.abstract: A class-action suit by Silicon Valley engineers against companies including Google, Apple and Intel has revealed details of an agreement among them not to cold-call one another’s employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Tech companies love new ideas, unless they belong to someone else. Then any breakthroughs must be neutralized or bought. Silicon Valley executives know all too well that a competitor’s unchecked innovation can quickly topple the mightiest tech titan.

articles.headline: A Bastion for Israel, Seething Inside
articles.snippet: A dispute over Israel at The New Republic has spilled out of the newsroom and into the public realm, leading to questions over the magazine’s new editorial stance.
articles.abstract: A dispute over Israel at The New Republic has spilled out of the newsroom and into the public realm, leading to questions over the magazine’s new editorial stance.
articles.lead_paragraph: When John Judis, a longtime senior editor at The New Republic, published a book examining the role of the pro-Zionist lobby in persuading President Harry S. Truman to support the founding of the Jewish state in 1948, he expected strong criticism, and he has certainly gotten it.

articles.headline: Slum Dwellers in Caracas Ask, What Protests?
articles.snippet: While the middle and upper classes have dug in against President Nicolás Maduro’s government, the poor have in large part stayed away.
articles.abstract: While the middle and upper classes have dug in against President Nicolás Maduro’s government, the poor have in large part stayed away.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — On the east side of this capital city, where the rich people tend to live, most children have stayed home from school for more than a week, protest bonfires burn in the streets at night, stores shut early and carnival celebrations have been canceled.

articles.headline: Ukraine Mobilizes Reserve Troops, Threatening War
articles.snippet: Russia’s move to seize control of Ukraine’s Crimean Peninsula on Saturday led Ukraine to call up its military reserves on Sunday and warn Moscow against further incursions.
articles.abstract: Russia’s move to seize control of Ukraine’s Crimean Peninsula on Saturday led Ukraine to call up its military reserves on Sunday and warn Moscow against further incursions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — Russia’s move to seize control of Ukraine’s Crimean Peninsula on Saturday led Ukraine to call up its military reserves on Sunday and warn Moscow against further incursions as Western powers scrambled to find a response to the crisis.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Break Up the Bank? It’s Not for You to Ask
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase is trying to stop a shareholder’s proposal from going to a vote at its annual meeting.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase is trying to stop a shareholder’s proposal from going to a vote at its annual meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase is trying to put its troubles behind it. Having agreed to pay a $13 billion settlement to the government for its past mortgage-lending misdeeds, it wants to move on. At the big “Investor Day” meeting with shareholders last week, Jamie Dimon, its chief executive, and his top lieutenants extolled the bank’s strong and diversified position in its four main businesses. “I am so damn proud of this company,” Mr. Dimon exclaimed.

articles.headline: Pampered Guests and Feuding Hosts at Claridge’s Hotel
articles.snippet: British and Irish magnates are squabbling over the ownership of Claridge’s, the London luxury hotel.
articles.abstract: British and Irish magnates are squabbling over the ownership of Claridge’s, the London luxury hotel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few trophies, it would seem, are more seductive to tycoons than Claridge’s, the grande dame of luxury London hotels, which has a long history of tempting buyers and provoking gentlemen’s quarrels.
articles.byline: By Doreen Carvajal and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Making Russia Pay? It’s Not So Simple
articles.snippet: President Obama has warned Russia that “there will be costs” for a military intervention in Ukraine. But the U.S. has few options for imposing such costs, and recent history has shown that Russia has been willing to absorb any such fallout.
articles.abstract: President Obama has warned Russia that “there will be costs” for a military intervention in Ukraine. But the U.S. has few options for imposing such costs, and recent history has shown that Russia has been willing to absorb any such fallout.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has warned Russia that “there will be costs” for a military intervention in Ukraine. But the United States has few palatable options for imposing such costs, and recent history has shown that when it considers its interests at stake, Russia has been willing to pay the price.

articles.headline: The Monuments of Tech
articles.snippet: The workplaces of Facebook, Twitter and Google may look whimsical. But each design is calculated to mirror its company’s values and culture.
articles.abstract: The workplaces of Facebook, Twitter and Google may look whimsical. But each design is calculated to mirror its company’s values and culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big Internet companies love to talk about how they are “disrupting” one thing or another, but they still want what big companies have always wanted: workplaces that memorialize their products and values.

articles.headline: Missions Signal a Growing Role for Mormon Women
articles.snippet: A sharp rise in the number of female missionaries points to a fundamental shift for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
articles.abstract: A sharp rise in the number of female missionaries points to a fundamental shift for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAEJEON, South Korea — Ashley Farr, once Miss North Salt Lake Teen USA, is the first in her family’s long line of Mormon women to become a missionary, and in December she embarked on her new life in this gray corner of Asia. She packed her bag according to the church’s precise instructions: skirts that cover the knee, only one pair of pants, earrings that dangle no longer than one inch, and subtle but flattering makeup, modeled in  photos on the church’s website.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Rise in Bigotry Fuels Massacre Inside Myanmar
articles.snippet: Violence against the Rohingya minority has presented a test for Myanmar’s leaders, who have done little to rein in the ethnic killings even as they pursue broad political and economic reforms.
articles.abstract: Violence against the Rohingya minority has presented a test for Myanmar’s leaders, who have done little to rein in the ethnic killings even as they pursue broad political and economic reforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: DU CHEE YAR TAN, Myanmar — Under the pale moon of Jan. 13, Zaw Patha watched from her bamboo house as Mohmach, 15, her eldest child, was dragged from the kiosk where he slept as guardian of the family business.

articles.headline: Obama’s New Political Chief Tries to Reassure Democrats
articles.snippet: The ascension of David Simas is meant as a message that the White House is serious about defending the party’s control of the Senate and mitigating losses in the House.
articles.abstract: The ascension of David Simas is meant as a message that the White House is serious about defending the party’s control of the Senate and mitigating losses in the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — David Simas left nothing to chance when he ran for the Taunton, Mass., school board at the age of 22. He packed the kickoff fund-raiser at the Portuguese-American Civic Club with his extended family, took his mother with him to knock on 5,000 doors and left a handwritten note if no one was home: “Sorry I missed you. David.”

articles.headline: Big-Money Donors Demand Larger Say in Campaign Strategy
articles.snippet: In both parties, elite donors who once deferred to “super PAC” leaders to determine the best use of their money are now taking a central role in shaping campaigns.
articles.abstract: In both parties, elite donors who once deferred to “super PAC” leaders to determine the best use of their money are now taking a central role in shaping campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Republican donors who have financed the party’s vast outside-spending machine are turning against the consultants and political strategists they once lavished with hundreds of millions of dollars.

articles.headline: Foreign Buyers Eyeing Forbes Magazine, a Chronicler of the World’s Wealthiest
articles.snippet: All good things come to an end, even for the rich, and sometime this month, Forbes will probably pass out of family control and into the hands of a foreign owner.
articles.abstract: All good things come to an end, even for the rich, and sometime this month, Forbes will probably pass out of family control and into the hands of a foreign owner.
articles.lead_paragraph: Growing up in the Midwest, my idea of rich was my dentist, who lived a few blocks away and had a split-level that was bigger than the rest of ours and a Cadillac in the driveway. Then I saw a copy of Forbes in his office and realized there was a different sort of wealth, a gossamer existence beyond my wildest imaginings.

articles.headline: Tiny Digital Publisher to Put Newsweek Back in Print
articles.snippet: IBT Media, a small digital publishing company that bought Newsweek for a pittance last summer, is poised to place the magazine on newsstands again this Friday.
articles.abstract: IBT Media, a small digital publishing company that bought Newsweek for a pittance last summer, is poised to place the magazine on newsstands again this Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Graham family, longtime newspaper publishers, gave up and sold it for a dollar. The media mogul Barry Diller spent tens of millions trying to revive it, only to throw in the towel. Even Mr. Diller’s star editor, Tina Brown, could not stop it from going out of print.

articles.headline: When Start-Ups Don’t Lock the Doors
articles.snippet: For new tech companies, developing features and acquiring users tends to be a priority over securing customer data, leaving them vulnerable to security breaches.
articles.abstract: For new tech companies, developing features and acquiring users tends to be a priority over securing customer data, leaving them vulnerable to security breaches.
articles.lead_paragraph: Young tech companies have a long list of to-dos. Signing up users and raising money are usually at the top of the list.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: The Airport Chaplain, Now Offering Earthly Aid
articles.snippet: Ministers in various denominations help passengers in dire straits financially and anyone in need of a spiritual lift at the airport.
articles.abstract: Ministers in various denominations help passengers in dire straits financially and anyone in need of a spiritual lift at the airport.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The young man, weighed down by luggage and despair, was a first-time flier on his way to a funeral in Detroit. His father’s.

articles.headline: Putin Engages in Test of Will Over Ukraine
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has pursued his strategy with subterfuge, propaganda and brazen military threat, taking aim as much at the United States and Europe as Ukraine itself.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has pursued his strategy with subterfuge, propaganda and brazen military threat, taking aim as much at the United States and Europe as Ukraine itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin has left little doubt he intends to cripple Ukraine’s new government, forcing it to make concessions or face the de facto partition of areas populated predominantly by ethnic Russians, from the Crimea to Odessa to the industrial heartland in the east.

articles.headline: Pressure Rising as Obama Works to Rein In Russia
articles.snippet: President Obama rallied allies and approved a series of diplomatic and economic moves intended to isolate Moscow and prevent it from seizing more Ukrainian territory.
articles.abstract: President Obama rallied allies and approved a series of diplomatic and economic moves intended to isolate Moscow and prevent it from seizing more Ukrainian territory.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Russia dispatched more forces and tightened its grip on the Crimean Peninsula on Sunday, President Obama embarked on a strategy intended to isolate Moscow and prevent it from seizing more Ukrainian territory even as he was pressured at home to respond more forcefully.

articles.headline: In General Motors Recalls, Inaction and Trail of Fatal Crashes
articles.snippet: G.M. has been sued, and now faces an investigation by the safety agency and the possibility of a criminal investigation, similar to the criminal inquiry Toyota is facing after recalls over the unintended acceleration of its vehicles.
articles.abstract: G.M. has been sued, and now faces an investigation by the safety agency and the possibility of a criminal investigation, similar to the criminal inquiry Toyota is facing after recalls over the unintended acceleration of its vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Laura Christian, July 29, 2005, was the worst kind of anniversary.

articles.headline: High-Interest Web Banks on the Rise in China
articles.snippet: The sector’s growth is intensifying competition for deposits and putting pressure on state-run banks, which are struggling with a severe cash squeeze.
articles.abstract: The sector’s growth is intensifying competition for deposits and putting pressure on state-run banks, which are struggling with a severe cash squeeze.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Last June, an affiliate of the Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba made an offer to its hundreds of millions of users: Give us your cash, and we will pay more than Chinese banks will.

articles.headline: Democrats Try Wooing Ones Who Got Away: White Men
articles.snippet: An internal debate over how hard the party should work to win over white men has emerged as support from female and minority voters grows.
articles.abstract: An internal debate over how hard the party should work to win over white men has emerged as support from female and minority voters grows.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROYAL OAK, Mich. — Frank Houston knows something about the longtime estrangement of white men from the Democratic Party. His family roots are in nearby Macomb County, the symbolic home of working-class Reagan Democrats who, distressed by economic and social tumult, decided a liberal Democratic Party had left them, not the other way around.

articles.headline: New Law’s Demands on Doctors Have Many Seeking a Network
articles.snippet: The Affordable Care Act has many doctors in private practice anxious about the future as those employed by hospital systems are enjoying security in a changing landscape.
articles.abstract: The Affordable Care Act has many doctors in private practice anxious about the future as those employed by hospital systems are enjoying security in a changing landscape.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAYLORSVILLE, Ky. — Dr. Sven Jonsson, a primary care physician in this rural community, is seeing a steady tide of new patients under President Obama’s health care law, the Affordable Care Act. And so far, it is working out for him. His employer, a big hospital system, provides expensive equipment, takes care of bureaucratic chores and has buffered him from the turmoil of his rapidly changing business.

articles.headline: Markets Fall as Impasse in Ukraine Intensifies
articles.snippet: As tension between Moscow and Kiev escalated, the crisis appeared to unsettle investors who had already been nervous about shaky emerging market economies.
articles.abstract: As tension between Moscow and Kiev escalated, the crisis appeared to unsettle investors who had already been nervous about shaky emerging market economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The escalating crisis in Ukraine created turmoil in global markets on Monday, hitting stocks from Wall Street to Ukraine and causing a spike in oil and natural gas prices that could reach into consumers’ wallets.
articles.byline: By David Jolly and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Citigroup Affiliate’s Troubles Multiply as Money-Laundering Subpoenas Follow Fraud
articles.snippet: Banamex USA, a banking affiliate that handles transactions across the Mexican border, has become entangled in an investigation into compliance with rules on the monitoring of financial transfers.
articles.abstract: Banamex USA, a banking affiliate that handles transactions across the Mexican border, has become entangled in an investigation into compliance with rules on the monitoring of financial transfers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:16 p.m. | A headache is growing for Citigroup as a banking affiliate involved in money transfers across the Mexican border has become ensnared in a criminal investigation.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
